abstract: A key for accessing container values.
overview:
## Overview

You can create custom container values by extending the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ContainerValues] structure with new properties. First declare a new container value key type and specify a value for the required [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ContainerValueKey/defaultValue] property:

The Swift compiler automatically infers the associated [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ContainerValueKey/Value] type as the type you specify for the default value. Then use the key to define a new container value property:

Clients of your container value never use the key directly. Instead, they use the key path of your custom container value property. To set the container value for a view, add the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/containerValue(_:_:)] view modifier to that view:

As a convenience, you can also define a dedicated view modifier to apply this container value:

This improves clarity at the call site:

To read the container value, use `Group(subviews:)` on a containing view, and then access the container value on members of that collection.

In practice, this will mostly be used by views that contain multiple other views to extract information from their subviews. You could turn the example above into such a container view as follows:

items.description: The type of value produced by the container value.
items.name: Value

items.description: The default value of the container value.
items.name: defaultValue

items.description: An opaque value representing a subview of another view.
items.name: Subview

items.description: An opaque collection representing the subviews of view.
items.name: SubviewsCollection

items.description: Sets a particular container value of a view.
items.name: containerValue(_:_:)

items.description: A collection of container values associated with a given view.
items.name: ContainerValues

title: ContainerValueKey
